video.title: Final Fantasy VII Rebirth | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
The final novel in
my Jacques McKeown trilogy,

Will Leave the
Galaxy for Good, is now available

on audible.com. Tell them
Yahtzee sent ya. They won&#39;t care.
Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Hello, and welcome to my review of Final Fantasy 
7 Remake, Episode Two. Oh, sorry, I must have

briefly flashed into a fucking sensible timeline 
for a moment there. You know what, title namers?

You win. Words officially don&#39;t mean anything. 
Future video game academics will just have to

intuit that Rebirth is the sequel to Remake 
somehow. Guess they could always look it up,

but words don&#39;t mean anything anymore so they&#39;d 
have to use the new Bullshit Decimal System

where it&#39;s filed under Mangrove Underpants dot 
Catalepsy. Right, sorry, got it out of my system,

now. So, having progressed through a hearty .5% of 
the original game&#39;s plot in Final Fantasy 7 Remake

Episode Spooge, Final Fantasy 7 Remake Episode 
Dingbat opens with Cloud Strife, Mr. T, Manic

Pixie Dream Girl A, Mr. T&#39;s dog and Manic Pixie 
Dream Girl B embarking upon what was originally

the middle third of the game, which, speaking as 
someone with still only a passing acquaintance

with the original, seems to have consisted largely 
of pissing about. There&#39;s a scene early on where

Manic Pixie Dream Girl B - the wholesome one, 
not the one who dresses like a crossfit-themed

dominatrix - gleefully does a little skip and 
goes &quot;That&#39;s the first step on our new journey!&quot;

And I very clearly remember yelling at the screen. 
&quot;Journey to where? To do what?&quot; We have a vague

notion that our goal is to stop Sephiroth, but we 
don&#39;t know how to do that or where the bugger is,

the most reliable method we&#39;ve had for finding 
him so far is to feed Cloud expired prescription

meds until he hallucinates him again. There&#39;s a 
bunch of weird pale blokes in robes congregating

towards something and Cloud gets it into his 
head that they&#39;ll lead them to Sephiroth,

but they could also be dehydrated Emperor 
Palpatine cosplayers for all the evidence

presented. I do note that following them just 
happens to take us through a luxury cruise,

a beach resort and a theme park, at every one of 
which the manic pixie affiliated portion of the

entourage goes &quot;Oh hey well since we&#39;re here...&quot; 
Yeah, good hustle, girls. I&#39;ve tried that one a

few times. &quot;No really, this vat of ice cream is 
totally a business expense, Nick, it&#39;s research

for the next time I review a Kirby game.&quot; So for 
a large part the plot of Final Fantasy 7 Kumquat

feels directionless and lacking in urgency. 
It&#39;s Persona 3 syndrome again where the first

nine hundred hours of gameplay is summarised 
in one paragraph of the Wikipedia plot summary.

And the lack of prevailing wind combined with the 
commitment to adapting the goofier elements of the

original does tend to fuck up the emotional tone. 
There&#39;s a subplot in the midgame where Barrett

has to confront a former comrade who&#39;s gone 
insane with grief and PTSD and ends up having

to put him out of his misery and it&#39;s actually 
tragic and well told and emotionally engaging,

but then while Barrett is crying over the body 
of his friend, a fucking circus strongman in a

cape and little red pants shows up in a monster 
truck and attempts to alleviate Barrett&#39;s grief

by strategically flexing at him. Not for the 
first time, playing through these remakes as

a non-fan feels like being a new boyfriend in 
a well established friend group. Especially

when Manic Pixie Dream Girl C shows up, the 
ninja girl who gets introduced about nine

times before officially joining the party, always 
presented like the game was convinced I was going

to fall in love with the kooky moo and her clumsy 
antics, when in reality I was mostly cringing and

worrying about how this was going to affect the 
manic pixie dream girl tag team rota. Blimey,

how much can one man be manic pixie dream 
girled without going into diabetic shock?

But moving on. New for Final Fantasy 
7 Balustrade is open world gameplay,

including having to unlock radio towers, 
climb up sequences of yellow painted ledges,

and crafting mechanics. And try to imagine my 
face transitioning through one of those Faces

of Meth photo sequences as I read those out. It&#39;s 
not that I kneejerk hate yellow paint ledges like

Green Lantern without a stepladder, it&#39;s that 
in this game they&#39;re always laid out in flat,

tedious sequences where all you do is hold 
up to slowly ascend like a brain damaged

parakeet looking for the cuttlefish. Who the 
fuck is Chadley anyway, I looked it up and I

know they weren&#39;t in the original game, who 
are they to muscle their way into the remake

like K-Pop Data from Star Trek and oblige us 
to do all this radio tower twattery. Still,

it&#39;s only an open world game in the sense that 
Nicholas Cage is a good actor - it&#39;s only true

about half the time. Prolonged periods are spent 
away from the open world in linear story missions.

Unnecessarily prolonged, perhaps, but not quite 
as much as the ones in the first game were.

In fact, I find I generally enjoyed the combat 
more, too, I can&#39;t quite put my finger on how

it&#39;s changed unless it&#39;s just that a few more of 
my brain cells have died since then. But as the

party continued to accrue new members, every 
time I was forced by contrived story reasons

to switch them around to maximize manic pixie 
efficiency or whatever I&#39;d make a noise like a

frustrated walrus trying to open a ring pull tuna 
can sorta like this &quot;NYAAAAOOOOOORH&quot; - &#39;cos I knew

it meant having to spend another ten minutes in 
the fucking menus swapping their Materia around,

spending their upgrade points, managing equipment, 
making sure none of them have pooey nappies,

so that was annoying. But that&#39;s only for combat, 
and combat seems to be something Final Fantasy

7 Porridge only falls back on when it can&#39;t 
think of another bloody minigame. In the grand

Final Fantasy 8 tradition one of the main side 
activities is an anomalously popular collectible

card game, and I tend to avoid such things in 
RPGs because inevitably they&#39;ll explain the rules

and inevitably I&#39;ll listen with my mouth 
hanging open and the Inspector Gadget theme

tune running through my head and then after the 
tutorial never play it or think about it again.

But then there&#39;s a whole chapter of the critical 
path devoted to a tournament of this fucking

game that I had to opt out of, and when I heard 
the incredulous voice of the tournament manager

asking if I was really quitting, my stubborn pride 
forced me to back down and learn this stupid card

game I didn&#39;t find fun just so an NPC wouldn&#39;t 
make a disappointed face. Probably a me problem,

but it&#39;s just the start of the minigame 
safari. There&#39;s motorbiking, chocobo wrangling,

rock&#39;em sock&#39;em robots, dolphin riding, 
a veritable buffet of rhythm challenges,

although now I&#39;m thinking about it the 
original was about as rife with minigames,

and tended to be much worse at explaining 
them. In fact, cards on the table, lol,

I enjoyed playing Final Fantasy 7 Remake Part 
Knickerbocker more than I enjoyed Final Fantasy

7 Remake Part Jockstrap, and probably 
more than I&#39;d enjoy playing the original,

but I still don&#39;t *like* it that much. The 
way we speed from concept to concept indulging

five hundred different game mechanics makes 
the game feel a mile wide and an inch thick,

and every time one of the manic pixie dream girls 
emphasises their feelings by holding up two fists

under their chin and doing a little partial squat, 
it really, really looks like they&#39;re farting.
